name: Rock

feedback.Physical object: A rock exists physically and can be directly touched and observed.
feedback.Man-made / synthetic: Rocks are natural formations, not manufactured by humans.
feedback.Biological or biologically-inspired: Rocks are not living and do not exhibit biological characteristics.
feedback.Fixed/static: Rocks do not change position or form by themselves under normal conditions.
feedback.Structural: Rocks contribute to the structure of landscapes or built forms as foundational or supporting elements.
feedback.Perceptible: They are accessible to human senses — touch, sight, and sometimes sound (when struck).
feedback.Material form: Rocks are solid matter composed of minerals, not abstract or virtual.
feedback.Passive: They do not produce any effect or output intentionally.
feedback.Purposeful / intentional: Rocks have no intended function or goal — they are not designed or purposeful.
feedback.Emits output / produces effect: They do not inherently emit energy or effects, though they may passively affect surroundings (e.g., blocking wind).
feedback.Processes or regulates logic/signals: They do not participate in any logical, computational, or signaling activity.
feedback.Transforms or modifies internal state: They are generally inert and do not change form without external force.
feedback.Interacts with humans directly: Interaction is incidental — humans can use or touch rocks, but the rock itself does not engage.
feedback.Part of a larger system: Can be part of geological systems, but this encoding omits it unless foregrounded.
feedback.Autonomous in function: They have no function, autonomy, or internal behavior.
feedback.System-critical: No single rock is typically critical to a system’s operation or survival.
feedback.Symbolic / representational: Rocks may be symbolic in specific contexts (e.g., gravestones), but not generically.
feedback.Communicative: They do not convey messages or symbolic content inherently.
feedback.Logical / rule-based: They do not operate via logic or structure beyond physical properties.
feedback.Hierarchical / modular: They are undifferentiated masses, not composed of functional modules or parts.
feedback.Behavior-guiding: They do not instruct or guide behavior unless symbolically framed.
feedback.Self-referential / meta-conceptual: They have no conceptual or reflective quality.
feedback.Temporal: Though they exist through time, they do not track, express, or change with temporal structure.
feedback.Contextual abstraction: A rock is what it is — it does not change identity based on social or conceptual framing.
feedback.Socially / culturally constructed: Their existence does not rely on cultural consensus.
feedback.Defined by a group/system: They are not labeled or regulated by institutional systems inherently.
feedback.Linked to identity or role: They do not signify role or identity unless used in symbolic design.
feedback.Regulated / governed: Rocks are not subjects of governance or institutional control.
feedback.Teachable / transmissible: They are objects of study, but not themselves didactic.
feedback.Visible: They are typically observed visually — often noted for color, shape, and size.
feedback.Context-sensitive: They do not vary semantically across cultural or social settings in this encoding.
feedback.Widely known: Rocks are universally known and referenced in all cultures as basic natural objects.

description: A natural, solid aggregate of minerals — stable, perceptible, passive, and widely recognized across cultures.

name: Bridge

feedback.Physical object: A bridge is a tangible structure occupying space and constructed from physical materials.
feedback.Man-made / synthetic: Bridges are engineered and built by humans using intentional design and artificial materials.
feedback.Biological or biologically-inspired: Although it may mimic natural forms, the bridge itself is not biological or derived from biological systems.
feedback.Fixed/static: A bridge is stationary and anchored to its environment, with no moving parts as part of its core identity.
feedback.Structural: It functions as a load-bearing structure designed to span space and connect locations.
feedback.Perceptible: It is visually and physically perceivable — one can walk on, touch, and observe it.
feedback.Material form: Made of materials such as concrete, steel, wood — it has a persistent and manipulable physical form.
feedback.Passive: It does not produce effects on its own — it enables other actions (e.g., crossing) but does not act autonomously.
feedback.Purposeful / intentional: It serves a clear human-defined function: enabling traversal over obstacles like rivers or roads.
feedback.Emits output / produces effect: Omitted — the bridge does not output energy, signal, or action directly.
feedback.Processes or regulates logic/signals: It contains no computational logic or signal processing inherent to its structure.
feedback.Transforms or modifies internal state: Its structure is stable and not dynamically altered in use — no transformative behavior.
feedback.Interacts with humans directly: Humans traverse and engage with it physically — walking, driving, building upon it.
feedback.Part of a larger system: It connects with roads, transit systems, or architectural networks — embedded within infrastructure.
feedback.Autonomous in function: It does not operate independently — it is static and non-autonomous.
feedback.System-critical: In many cases, it is essential infrastructure; failure could cause major disruption or danger.
feedback.Symbolic / representational: Omitted here — though metaphorically symbolic in some contexts, not inherently so in a baseline bridge.
feedback.Communicative: It does not intentionally transmit information or messages.
feedback.Logical / rule-based: While engineered with rules, it does not encode or process logic in operation.
feedback.Hierarchical / modular: Bridges often contain modular substructures (e.g., beams, trusses, spans), forming a functional hierarchy.
feedback.Behavior-guiding: Not inherently instructional — it guides motion physically but not symbolically or intentionally.
feedback.Self-referential / meta-conceptual: It does not reference itself or serve as a meta-concept.
feedback.Temporal: While it exists over time, it does not express or manage temporality as part of its identity.
feedback.Contextual abstraction: Its function is mostly consistent across contexts; minor variation exists but not enough to encode this trait.
feedback.Socially / culturally constructed: Its role and significance are defined by human society — bridges represent shared norms of transit and infrastructure.
feedback.Defined by a group/system: Governed and categorized by city, national, or engineering standards and institutions.
feedback.Linked to identity or role: Not encoded here — it doesn't signify role or personal/social identity in its baseline form.
feedback.Regulated / governed: Subject to inspection, maintenance, zoning, and engineering laws and codes.
feedback.Teachable / transmissible: Bridges are studied in architecture and civil engineering — their form and function are transmissible knowledge.
feedback.Visible: Bridges are visually prominent architectural features and navigational landmarks.
feedback.Context-sensitive: Their design and significance often vary by geography, climate, and urban context.
feedback.Widely known: Bridges are universally recognized structures with clear function across nearly all cultures and regions.

description: A human-engineered structure that spans physical space to support passage, regulated and integrated into broader infrastructure — functional, structural, visible, and socially embedded.

name: Oak Tree

feedback.Physical object: An oak tree occupies space and has a tangible, measurable physical presence — it is not conceptual or virtual.
feedback.Man-made / synthetic: It is a natural organism, not designed, fabricated, or constructed by humans.
feedback.Biological or biologically-inspired: It is a naturally occurring organism, governed by biological processes like growth, respiration, and reproduction.
feedback.Fixed/static: Though it changes over time, it is rooted in one place and does not locomote or change spatial position.
feedback.Structural: Its form supports weight, organizes internal components (e.g., trunk, branches), and serves as a scaffold for other entities (e.g., nests, vines).
feedback.Perceptible: It can be seen, touched, smelled, and heard (e.g., rustling), making it directly accessible to the senses.
feedback.Material form: Composed of organic matter — wood, bark, leaves — its identity is inseparable from its physical substance.
feedback.Passive: It does not act with intent; its behaviors arise from internal biology and environmental response without agency.
feedback.Purposeful / intentional: It does not have agency, goals, or designed intent — it acts only as biology dictates.
feedback.Emits output / produces effect: It affects its surroundings through byproducts and interactions — e.g., releasing oxygen, shedding leaves, casting shade.
feedback.Processes or regulates logic/signals: It does not handle logic, information, or signal processing — no circuitry or symbolic control.
feedback.Transforms or modifies internal state: It changes as it grows, responds to seasons, stores nutrients, and heals after damage.
feedback.Interacts with humans directly: It does not actively engage or interface with humans — any interaction is incidental or passive.
feedback.Part of a larger system: It is embedded within ecological networks — interacting with soil, water, fungi, insects, and climate in mutual dependence.
feedback.Autonomous in function: Although self-regulating biologically, it does not meet the threshold for functional autonomy (no goal-seeking behavior or system independence).
feedback.System-critical: Most oak trees are not keystone entities whose absence would collapse a system — they are contributive but not singularly essential.
feedback.Symbolic / representational: In this generic instance, 'Oak Tree' has no embedded symbolic role — symbolic meaning would require cultural framing or narrative context.
feedback.Communicative: It does not encode or transmit intentional signals or messages.
feedback.Logical / rule-based: It does not embody or operate on formal rules or systems of logic.
feedback.Hierarchical / modular: While it has parts, it is not a modular or explicitly hierarchical system in a designed or conceptual sense.
feedback.Behavior-guiding: It does not influence behavior via intention, symbolism, or instruction.
feedback.Self-referential / meta-conceptual: It does not represent itself, reflect on its nature, or express meta-level ideas.
feedback.Temporal: Excluded in this encoding due to lack of semantic emphasis in the name or framing; while trees change over time, this version omits it absent explicit focus on seasonality or lifecycle.
feedback.Contextual abstraction: Its meaning does not shift across contexts or require interpretive abstraction — it is a concrete biological entity.
feedback.Socially / culturally constructed: Its identity as an oak tree is based in biology, not social agreement or cultural fabrication.
feedback.Defined by a group/system: It is not defined or regulated by a group, institution, or classification system (beyond biological taxonomy, which is not identity-defining here).
feedback.Linked to identity or role: It does not signify a social role, profession, or identity-bearing function.
feedback.Regulated / governed: It is not subject to institutional rules or governance.
feedback.Teachable / transmissible: The object itself is not knowledge-bearing or educational in form — it can be studied, but it does not teach.
feedback.Visible: Subsumed under 'Perceptible' and excluded here for compression — perceptibility already covers visual salience.
feedback.Context-sensitive: Excluded under the minimalist rule — while oaks respond to environment, this version does not emphasize context-specific traits or dependencies.
feedback.Widely known: The label 'Oak Tree' does not indicate symbolic fame, widespread cultural meaning, or iconic recognition — so this is omitted in the absence of framing to support it.

description: A rooted biological organism defined by passive structure, natural growth, and ecosystem participation — perceptible, material, and physically embedded without abstract or symbolic identity.

name: Candle

feedback.Physical object: A candle has tangible form and mass and can be perceived through touch and sight.
feedback.Man-made / synthetic: Candles are created intentionally by humans, often from processed wax and wicks.
feedback.Biological or biologically-inspired: It is not a biological entity nor inspired by living systems.
feedback.Fixed/static: The base structure of a candle remains stationary during use, even as it burns down.
feedback.Structural: It does not provide structural support or serve as a load-bearing component.
feedback.Perceptible: It is experienced via multiple senses — light, smell, warmth, and sight.
feedback.Material form: Constructed of wax and wick, it has a consistent material identity.
feedback.Passive: It acts only when lit, producing light actively — so 'Passive' is excluded.
feedback.Purposeful / intentional: It is designed to produce light and atmosphere, often with ritual or practical intent.
feedback.Emits output / produces effect: Once lit, it emits light, heat, and sometimes scent — clear physical outputs.
feedback.Processes or regulates logic/signals: It performs no signal processing or logical operations.
feedback.Transforms or modifies internal state: As it burns, its form (wax) is consumed — a clear transformation over time.
feedback.Interacts with humans directly: Omitted — it is used by humans but does not respond or adapt.
feedback.Part of a larger system: Not required by identity, even if it may participate in rituals or grouped use.
feedback.Autonomous in function: It sustains combustion after ignition, but lacks control or active behavior.
feedback.System-critical: A candle is not essential to the functioning of any system.
feedback.Symbolic / representational: Symbolic uses are common but not inherent — omitted under baseline encoding.
feedback.Communicative: Does not encode or transmit messages intentionally.
feedback.Logical / rule-based: Obeys physics but does not express or follow logical rules.
feedback.Hierarchical / modular: It is a single object, not a system of subsystems.
feedback.Behavior-guiding: Does not direct behavior unless interpreted symbolically.
feedback.Self-referential / meta-conceptual: It is not reflective or recursive in meaning.
feedback.Temporal: Its change over time is visible, but this is not encoded without explicit temporal framing.
feedback.Contextual abstraction: Its identity remains consistent regardless of use case.
feedback.Socially / culturally constructed: Cultural meaning exists but is excluded here for compression.
feedback.Defined by a group/system: Not institutionally defined in its identity.
feedback.Linked to identity or role: It is not role-defining or identity-linked.
feedback.Regulated / governed: May be governed in use (e.g. fire safety), but not as part of intrinsic identity.
feedback.Teachable / transmissible: Its use is taught, but it does not carry information or teach inherently.
feedback.Visible: Omitted to avoid redundancy — included under 'Perceptible'.
feedback.Context-sensitive: Meaning may shift, but this is excluded in baseline encoding.
feedback.Widely known: Commonplace, but not sufficient for trait inclusion under strict encoding.

description: A human-made object that emits light and heat when ignited — functional, perceptible, and materially simple, without symbolic or social encoding in its baseline form.

name: Clock

feedback.Physical object: A clock is a physical, tangible device that exists in material space and can be observed or manipulated.
feedback.Man-made / synthetic: Clocks are designed, built, and maintained by humans using artificial materials and systems.
feedback.Biological or biologically-inspired: A clock is not a biological system nor modeled on one.
feedback.Fixed/static: While its internal components move, the device itself remains in a fixed position during typical use.
feedback.Structural: It is not used as a support structure and does not serve an architectural load-bearing purpose.
feedback.Perceptible: It is directly observable through sight and sound — e.g., ticking hands or digital displays.
feedback.Material form: It is built from solid materials such as metal, plastic, and glass — it is not conceptual.
feedback.Passive: Not passive — it actively emits time-based output and transforms over time.
feedback.Purposeful / intentional: Clocks are built with the specific function of tracking and signaling time.
feedback.Emits output / produces effect: They produce regular outputs: visual time displays, ticking, alarms, or light pulses.
feedback.Processes or regulates logic/signals: Internally, they regulate and measure signals — mechanical or electronic — to keep time accurately.
feedback.Transforms or modifies internal state: Their displays change continuously as time progresses.
feedback.Interacts with humans directly: Users set, read, or respond to the clock’s output frequently.
feedback.Part of a larger system: Clocks may be networked, but this is not necessary to their baseline identity.
feedback.Autonomous in function: They function continuously once started, but do not adapt or respond to their environment.
feedback.System-critical: Most clocks are not individually system-critical in a baseline sense.
feedback.Symbolic / representational: Clocks symbolize the passage of time — a concept — and represent it continuously and abstractly.
feedback.Communicative: They convey information but not via dialogue or syntax — excluded in compression.
feedback.Logical / rule-based: They follow mechanical or electronic logic internally, but are not used to express conceptual rules externally.
feedback.Hierarchical / modular: Some are modular internally, but modularity is not essential to their core identity.
feedback.Behavior-guiding: They influence behavior through time awareness, but not in a directive or instructional way.
feedback.Self-referential / meta-conceptual: Most clocks do not reference themselves or represent abstract models.
feedback.Temporal: Time is the very dimension a clock expresses — this trait is fundamental to its purpose and representation.
feedback.Contextual abstraction: Clocks vary little in identity across settings — timekeeping remains the same.
feedback.Socially / culturally constructed: Time systems are socially constructed, but the clock mechanism functions independently of culture.
feedback.Defined by a group/system: While time zones are defined by groups, the clock itself is not.
feedback.Linked to identity or role: Clocks do not signify social identity or roles.
feedback.Regulated / governed: Timekeeping may be standardized, but not all clocks are regulated instruments.
feedback.Teachable / transmissible: Reading a clock is taught, but the object does not teach itself.
feedback.Context-sensitive: Clock function remains stable across usage contexts.
feedback.Widely known: Familiarity is not included under strict baseline unless iconic.

description: A human-crafted instrument that symbolizes and measures time through regulated, perceptible outputs — both functional and temporal in its core identity.

name: Book

feedback.Physical object: A book has a tangible presence and exists in physical space — it can be handled, stored, and transported.
feedback.Man-made / synthetic: Books are created by humans through deliberate design and production processes.
feedback.Biological or biologically-inspired: Books are not living systems nor based on biological models.
feedback.Fixed/static: Once printed or finalized, the content and structure of a book remain unchanged.
feedback.Structural: It is not load-bearing or architectural in nature.
feedback.Perceptible: It is readable through sight and touch; one can flip pages and view printed symbols.
feedback.Material form: Constructed from paper, ink, glue, and covers — clearly material and not virtual.
feedback.Passive: Books do not act on their own or emit effects unless interacted with — not included due to symbolic output.
feedback.Purposeful / intentional: Books are created with the intent to store, organize, and communicate specific content.
feedback.Emits output / produces effect: Omitted — any effects are interpretive or symbolic, not physical outputs like heat or light.
feedback.Processes or regulates logic/signals: The book contains logic in content but does not process or execute logic itself.
feedback.Transforms or modifies internal state: It does not change form or state autonomously.
feedback.Interacts with humans directly: Books are handled, read, and experienced directly by people.
feedback.Part of a larger system: Books may belong to libraries or curricula, but this is not required for the baseline form.
feedback.Autonomous in function: It cannot function or produce effect without human engagement.
feedback.System-critical: Books are important culturally but not typically critical to system survival.
feedback.Symbolic / representational: The essence of a book lies in its symbolic content — it encodes meaning through written language.
feedback.Communicative: Omitted under compression — communication is indirect via human interpretation.
feedback.Logical / rule-based: It may contain logic but does not embody or execute rules on its own.
feedback.Hierarchical / modular: Content may be structured, but the object itself is not modular.
feedback.Behavior-guiding: It may influence thoughts or behavior but not through built-in instruction.
feedback.Self-referential / meta-conceptual: Some books may be meta, but the object class 'book' is not inherently self-referential.
feedback.Temporal: It exists over time but does not represent or manage time inherently.
feedback.Contextual abstraction: Meaning varies by content, not the object form — excluded from the baseline.
feedback.Socially / culturally constructed: While books have social roles, this is excluded in baseline encoding unless specifically emphasized.
feedback.Defined by a group/system: Standards exist for publishing, but the identity of 'book' does not require institutional framing.
feedback.Linked to identity or role: Books do not define social roles themselves.
feedback.Regulated / governed: Publication may be governed, but not every book requires regulatory encoding.
feedback.Teachable / transmissible: While books convey knowledge, they are not intrinsically didactic in form.
feedback.Context-sensitive: A book's physical form does not shift meaning across contexts.
feedback.Widely known: Books are common but not encoded unless cultural prominence is central to identity.

description: A human-made physical object that stores symbolic content in static material form — readable, perceptible, and intentionally crafted for meaning transmission.

name: Dragon (Mythical)

feedback.Physical object: Though fictional, dragons are consistently represented with a tangible, physical form across myths — winged, scaled, and physically active.
feedback.Man-made / synthetic: Not included — dragons are not constructed artifacts but imagined biological entities.
feedback.Biological or biologically-inspired: Their anatomy borrows heavily from real-world animals (reptiles, bats, large predators).
feedback.Fixed/static: Omitted — dragons are described as dynamic, living beings.
feedback.Structural: Not applicable — they are not structural elements or architectural components.
feedback.Perceptible: Highly visual and often audible; dragons are depicted in art, film, and literature as sensory-rich beings.
feedback.Material form: Excluded — as mythical entities, dragons lack actual material instantiation despite being imagined in physical terms.
feedback.Passive: Dragons are active agents in myths, often aggressive or vigilant — not passive.
feedback.Purposeful / intentional: They are portrayed as having motives: guarding treasure, attacking villages, or testing heroes.
feedback.Emits output / produces effect: Fire-breathing, flight, roar — dragons produce clear fictional outputs within stories.
feedback.Processes or regulates logic/signals: Not included — dragons do not symbolize logical or computational behavior.
feedback.Transforms or modifies internal state: Omitted — dragons may undergo narrative arcs but not biologically internal transformation as core identity.
feedback.Interacts with humans directly: They frequently engage with heroes, villagers, or gods — forming pivotal narrative roles.
feedback.Part of a larger system: Excluded — while they appear in myth systems, the entity of 'dragon' is typically standalone.
feedback.Autonomous in function: Act independently, often as powerful solitary figures with no master.
feedback.System-critical: Not essential to any real-world or fictional ecosystem's continuity.
feedback.Symbolic / representational: Dragons represent many things: chaos, wisdom, greed, power — essential to their mythic function.
feedback.Communicative: They may speak, issue challenges, or serve as allegorical devices — communication is central in many depictions.
feedback.Logical / rule-based: Dragons do not embody systems of logic or formal reasoning.
feedback.Hierarchical / modular: Not modular — typically singular beings, not composed of interchangeable subsystems.
feedback.Behavior-guiding: Used in stories to shape moral lessons, courage, and taboo — they test or catalyze behavior.
feedback.Self-referential / meta-conceptual: Not inherently meta; they exist within narrative frames rather than as commentary.
feedback.Temporal: Time is not essential to their identity — omitted.
feedback.Contextual abstraction: The meaning of a dragon shifts drastically between cultures (e.g., European = evil; Chinese = wise and noble).
feedback.Socially / culturally constructed: Dragons are invented and sustained through cultural imagination and storytelling.
feedback.Defined by a group/system: Their characteristics are dictated by shared mythological conventions within societies.
feedback.Linked to identity or role: Symbolically tied to kingship, power, national identity (e.g., dragons in flags, houses, heraldry).
feedback.Regulated / governed: No governance applies; not a codified or official construct.
feedback.Teachable / transmissible: Stories of dragons are passed down, taught to children, and embedded in curricula and folklore.
feedback.Visible: Excluded — their visual representation is covered under 'Perceptible'.
feedback.Context-sensitive: A dragon’s moral role or behavior changes dramatically based on cultural setting or time period.
feedback.Widely known: Dragons are among the most globally recognized mythic beings — spanning continents and centuries.

description: A legendary creature with biological features and symbolic roles — autonomous, powerful, and deeply embedded in cultural myths across societies. Acts as both a narrative force and moral device in human storytelling.

name: Dragon (Actual)

feedback.Physical object: As a corporeal creature, a real dragon would have spatial presence, mass, and form — it occupies the physical world.
feedback.Man-made / synthetic: Omitted — a naturally evolved species, not artificially constructed.
feedback.Biological or biologically-inspired: Fully biological, exhibiting traits of respiration, metabolism, and organic structure.
feedback.Fixed/static: Not applicable — real dragons would move, hunt, and interact with their environment.
feedback.Structural: Does not serve as a structure or load-bearing element — it is an autonomous lifeform.
feedback.Perceptible: Would be observable through sensory input — sight, sound, and possibly smell (e.g., wings, roar, fire).
feedback.Material form: Has a definite, tangible body composed of biological tissues and systems.
feedback.Passive: Excluded — an active predator or intelligent species, not inert.
feedback.Purposeful / intentional: Exhibits behavior suggesting intent — seeking food, defending territory, reproducing.
feedback.Emits output / produces effect: Produces fire, sound, or flight — active outputs consistent with myth but grounded in biology.
feedback.Processes or regulates logic/signals: Not included — does not imply computational or signaling architecture beyond basic nervous systems.
feedback.Transforms or modifies internal state: Biological creatures metabolize energy, regulate heat, and adapt to stimuli.
feedback.Interacts with humans directly: Assuming such a creature exists in human space, direct encounters (hostile or neutral) would be likely.
feedback.Part of a larger system: Would function as part of an ecosystem — predator, apex species, or environmental influence.
feedback.Autonomous in function: Self-sustaining in movement, hunting, and other life functions.
feedback.System-critical: Not essential to ecosystem function on a global level — excluded.
feedback.Symbolic / representational: Not included — this version is not a metaphor but a literal creature.
feedback.Communicative: Omitted — unless language or signal behavior is proven, it is not a primary trait.
feedback.Logical / rule-based: Biological behavior is instinctual, not governed by logic rules — excluded.
feedback.Hierarchical / modular: Not modular in any abstract structural sense.
feedback.Behavior-guiding: Does not guide human behavior symbolically or ideologically.
feedback.Self-referential / meta-conceptual: Does not model itself or understand abstract categories.
feedback.Temporal: Exists in time, but temporality is not central to identity.
feedback.Contextual abstraction: Not an abstract or shifting symbol — physical identity is stable.
feedback.Socially / culturally constructed: It exists independently of human culture or stories.
feedback.Defined by a group/system: Identity does not depend on cultural definitions or frameworks.
feedback.Linked to identity or role: Not used as a symbol of identity in this literal biological framing.
feedback.Regulated / governed: No political or legal governance defines its existence.
feedback.Teachable / transmissible: Not a story or idea to be taught — it is an organism.
feedback.Visible: Can be directly observed in the environment — this is distinct from being symbolically 'known'.
feedback.Context-sensitive: Its meaning does not shift with context — identity is biologically fixed.
feedback.Widely known: If real, it would be world-famous — appearing in science, media, and global consciousness.

description: A real, biological organism exhibiting traits like flight, fire-breathing, and autonomous behavior. Not symbolic or mythic — a physical apex creature known for its powerful outputs and ecological role.
